Success Stories

Listen to what teachers are saying...

"A game can draw somebody in—the same ideas may be laid out on a piece of paper or in a textbook, but they don’t draw you in in the same way...You can fail, and you instantly find out what happens. Then you try again, and it’s not discouraging. It can challenge kids."

  • Ted Stanford, associate professor in the Department of Mathematical Sciences at New Mexico State

"With game-based learning, students become more engaged with their learning. They go from struggling to finding a way to overcome that struggle and start looking for solutions and innovating strategies on their learning. "

  • Ryan Read, technology teacher at Stillman Valley High School

"My experiences are almost exclusively positive, even though I had to make changes in certain situations to be sure the focus is not on the system but on the actual topic and school learning."

  • Philipp Staubitz, special education teacher

Math Snacks

Math Snacks, a game-based learning platform directed at middle school, did a thorough study on the game's impact. Before implementing Math Snacks, students showed significant gaps in understanding of ratios and number systems concepts. The study showed that students who were taught ratio and number line concepts with the aid of Math Snacks showed greater improvement than students taught more traditionally. This is seen in the graph to the left. Students were divided into two groups. All students took test 1 and had similar results. Group A was then taught the subject material and implemented games from Math Snacks. Group B was taught the content in a traditional method. Group A had greater success based on the results from test 2 that occurred five weeks later. Group B was then also taught with Math Snacks, and students’ success level caught up to group A, as shown with test 3. Click here to read more.

Algebra Champ


Algebra Champ is a one-player video game that helps students with algebra. The game was used in a study with students who have ADHD. Students played the game for 10 minutes in each math class for three weeks. Teachers noticed an increase in the attention span and motivation of students, as well as an increase in test scores. No conclusive results were drawn due to the small number of participants in the study. Teachers indicated that using the game in their class created a more relaxed environment. Click here to read more.

Keys to Implementing Game-Based Learning

Keep these practises in mind when implementing game-based learning into your own classroom.

1

Learning Goals

Ensure the game aligns with your learning goals. Will playing this game help students meet the desired target?

2

Practise the game yourself

Ask yourself, do the instructions for the game make sense? Is the game intrinsically motivating to play? Will it capture my students' interests?

3

Learner Needs

Consider the needs of your students. Does the game allow for different learning styles? Will any aspects of the game be inaccessible to some of your students?

4

Clear Expectations

Any activity can be abused by students. As a class, come up with a list of norms that the class will follow when playing the games.

5

Time

Playing a game once for a few minutes at the start of class will not transform your learning environment. Class time must be invested to play the game.

6

Variety of Instruction

Game-based learning should not be the sole form of instruction in the classroom. A variety of instructional methods should always be used.

7

Feedback

Ensure students receive formative feedback throughout the game. This should come from both the game itself and you as an educator.

8

Reflection

Reflection is a crucial piece of learning that is often overlooked. Both large and small group discussions, exit slips, and other forms of instruction should be used to help students consolidate their learning.
